issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The product is working as designed.
resolution.name: Not a Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
eucalyptus-console-3.4.0-0.0.2809.20131011git2cbbcc31.el6.noarch

Eucalyptus-console process has increased from ~20m to 3.3g of mem over several hours. We suspect that because the UI is causing other eucalyptus processes also running on this machine to fault due to the resource starvation. 

-This console is shared by QA at the moment so is getting used by multiple people. 
-This system is a multi-cluster, ha, multi-hypervisor. See topo in env section. 
Thanks, 
-M

comments.body: Let me take a crack at this this morning.

I logged in and out several times to a Euca cloud and I see the proxy memory go up by about 1MB or so each time. Starting around 18MB, ending around 30MB. That's something we need to track down.
I see # threads go up and down, so that seems OK.

Simply logging in with AWS acct brings memory up to 700MB over time as the public image caches fill up. I logged out/in again and memory went up to abotu 900MB and didn't go much higher, but after logging and navigating to the images screen (showing amazon images), memory crept up to about 1GB and then I could not login again. It is unclear why login is failing, but given when memory bumped up, I suspect there might be some correlation with the process of sending information to the browser, maybe related to marshalling into JSON.
One more note, lots of threads running. When things to south, I see about 130 threads running. Clearly with a single user, there should be no where that many threads running.

Simply logging out and back in with AWS creds drives up thread count every time. I'm going to wrap Timers module to add more debug.
With further debug, I'm able to name the timer threads doing cache fetches. When the proxy terminates, it dumps the names of the threads it is shutting down. There are only 16 threads assigned to image cache fetching as expected, whereas more generic (Thread-XX) threads are multiplying with more logins. Need to determine where those are spawned from.

Turns out I had a debug version of boto installed with my request logger which was not nicely cleaning up a logging thread. I'm back to normal boto and the thread behavior is as expected. Logging out drops the thread count back down to where it should be. Now to look at memory some more.

login with euca, twice. notice allocation spike each time that doesn't go away. stack exploration leads me to a malloc in the ssl crypto stuff. Maybe a client connection obj isn't being dereferenced properly.

We should test with a more recent version of Tornado, based on these posts:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12626064/tornado-memory-leak-on-dropped-connections
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14162950/memory-leak-in-tornado-generator-engine-with-try-finally-block-when-connections 
and this commit, which was included in Tornado 3.0...
https://github.com/facebook/tornado/commit/769bc52e11656788782a6e7a922ef646503f9ab0
Going to try Dowser to debug the memory leak, per instructions at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/python-tornado/D4kSwHg5da0

more information that comes from Dowser (which I was typing into IRC)

wow, memory creep is so gradual. almost not a big deal
I'm really not seeing anything horrible. Lots of sparklines that go zero to 1 or 2, and stay there.. that's fine
a bunch more that oscillate as login/logout happens
nothing with a nice ramp up.
going to try with aws logins now
I'll see some serious ramp-up as caches load for all the regions
That's an optimization I'd like to make.. .don't load a region cache if nobody has called for it yet.
cerealkillr ^^
w/ aws login and cache fill, I see boto objs ramping up. as those caches fill. np there.
kamalgill, cool thing here is we can simply do a find for "file" in the browser and see any file related objs held.

I've been logging in and out with an aws account. Thread are as expected. (16 for timers to manage the shared caches), 2 more for tornado and 1 for Dowser.
CPU with nobody logged in is fine.
Memory seems to have topped out as the image caches filled. Since I took this screen shot, it dropped a little even.

Proxy memory usage topped at 1.2gb for me (on my Mac).  clchost=10.111.5.78

Going to try on my Fedora 19 box since that's closer to the target deployment environment.

My QA proxy is at 3.0G.
21973 root      20   0 4664m 3.0g 4480 S 40.6 43.6  14:19.86 euca-console-se

Kicked off churn test on 10.111.5.4 can be viewed here: http://10.111.4.123/job/UI-stress-user-simulation/

VNC: 10.111.4.112:1

http://10.111.4.123/job/UI-stress-user-simulation-1/

VNC: 10.111.4.118:1

One notable behavior is this:
1) log-in and wait until all images cache (by unsetting owner='aws' in images landing). Region is at us-east.
2) change region to another (Oregon)
3) log-out and log-in again.

I see the memory spikes(700MB) when 1-3 followed. 

I feel strong impression that the memory consumption is related to huge image set for different regions. However there other image-related bugs (EUCA-7875) that makes debugging hard.

I did quick test, one with turning on 'all' aws images and turning it off.
For us-east region, when 'all' aws images are retrieved, the proxy consumes about 1.1 G physical memory. When it's disabled, proxy consumes about 300 MB memory.
when I tried all different regions, the memory consumption is less than 400MB, when 'all' image enumeration is disabled.

So, based on observation, memory on a QA setup with UI seems fairly stable when subjected to hours of churn testing. With a single user, max was 3.1 G steady. When 2 users were running, it held at 3.4 G.
I'm not sure why this is 3x higher than running on a Mac, but that's another thing to look into.
I've also watched threads and the expected number are running when users logout. The number goes up and down predictably.
Also, CPU load for the console process always returns down to a low value (1-2%).

I don't think this is a blocker. The original observation is simply that the steady state level of memory was reached.

[~dkavanagh]  [~kgill] 

Can you give a rough back of the napkin estimation of where the 3.4G of memory is being used within the console server process?

Yeah, all by default seems excessive. I agree.
On Oct 14, 2013 5:32 PM, "Sang-Min Park (JIRA)" <
The image caches are the majority of that. I'll have to run some tests to spit out size information of the boto structures involved to get a better accounting of that.

That would be great [~dkavanagh] !

I think [~mclark]  did some rough estimates with regard to the boto objects (specifically images). 

 [~mclark] ,

What did you end up with?
No easy answer. There are hidden costs(overhead) and no clear way to get sizes of custom objects.

Hi [~viglesias] [~dkavanagh] ,
On my system I was 'guesstimating'  about 4.5k per image obj.. This would be about ~238,000 image objects per gig and maybe around 700,000 image objects in our max mem case?

As David mentioned I don't think there's an easy way to reliably get the memory usage of a custom python object. From what I could find, pickling the object(s) into a buffer/string and getting that buffer's size (or pickle into a file and it's size) would give a decent rough estimation, and likely over estimate by accounting for shared objs. Seems reasonable, but I don't know if this is at all an accurate estimation?
Thanks,
-Matt
On my system...
In [13]: for i in images:
    print str(i.id) + ":" + str(sys.getsizeof(pickle.dumps(i)))
   ....:

We may want to use simplejson instead of Python's built-in json library, since there are memory issues when serializing large payloads using the built-in library.  See http://bugs.python.org/issue12778 and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11057712/huge-memory-usage-of-pythons-json-module

I suspect this may explain the difference in memory usage between our Macs (running Python 2.7) and the CentOS boxes (running Python 2.6).  The json library in Py 2.6 is ancient and terribly inefficient.

Pulling in simplejson a new dependency this late in the game is probably not going to fly for 3.4.0, but we should investigate it as an optimization for 3.4.1 IMO
